node.title: Victorian mum wages war on waste, one lunch box at a time
node.alt: A smiling woman wearing an apron holds a lunchbox full of healthy food.
node.description: No Packet November has gone online this year, but for the nutritionist behind the campaign, the message is still the same â€” get your kids eating better food with less waste and we all stand to benefit.
node.content:
["When Kyneton nutrition and health coach Kate Coleman noticed a child in her daughter's primary school class had seven packaged foods in her lunch box, she felt uneasy.", "\"Chips, biscuits, chocolate-covered food, fruit straps,\" she said.", "\"It was concerning looking at all the packaging and thinking of the processed ingredients the child was consuming.\"", "Since 2016 the No Packet November founder has been urging families\u00a0to ditch packaged snacks in lunch boxes.", "\"Packaged foods every now and again is fine \u2014 it's the world we live in,\" Ms Coleman said.", "\"But having them daily in lunch boxes in the amounts we do\u00a0I feel is leading to poor outcomes such as obesity, diabetes, allergies, and asthma.\"", "Ms Coleman is also worried about the environmental impacts of packaged food.", "\"It's just alarming by 2050 there could be more plastic in the ocean than fish,\" she said.", "\"I just think my children could be on a beach holiday by then, and there could be packets floating all around them.", "\"It's terrible, the knock-on effect to the fish and marine life, which also enters our food supply\u00a0\u2026 [we] could potentially end up digesting microplastic when we eat seafood.", "", "
Ms Coleman hopes her campaign will lead to less rubbish ending up in the ocean.(Supplied: Rich Horner)
", "
Simple changes
", "Ms Coleman said there were basic ways families could cut back on packaging.", "\"If sugar is in the top ingredients, that's an alarm bell that perhaps the kids don't need it,\" she said.", "\"The biggest thing for me is about the snacks \u2014 veggie sticks, cheese and olives, bliss balls, homemade muffins and biscuits, or buying things in bulk, such as a Greek yoghurt, can make a huge difference.\"", "At this time of year, the health expert usually goes into schools to teach basic recipes that most children can create at home, but due to pandemic restrictions, she has opted to create an online recipe book instead.", "The recipes are easy, cheap to make and\u00a0\"most of the time\" do not require an oven.", "", "
Chocolate zucchini slice with ganache is one of the snacks featured in Ms Coleman's recipe book.(Supplied)
", "\"I mix together oats, dates, seeds and some honey for bliss balls, mixing them in a food processor and getting the kids to roll them into balls in their hands, dipped in coconut,\" Ms Coleman said.", "\"Amazing how many kids go, 'Oh that's disgusting,' and then as soon as they taste it, they go, 'Oh that's really nice.'", "Try this\u00a0recipe from Ms Coleman's e-book:", "
Chocolate zucchini slice with ganache
", "Pre-heat oven to 180 degrees Celsius. Line a rectangular slice tin with baking paper.", "In a medium saucepan over low heat, combine oil, chocolate chips, and cocoa, whisking occasionally, until chips are melted and mixture is smooth.", "Remove from heat and whisk in the sugar. Now add the eggs and vanilla, and whisk until combined. Stir in the zucchini. Fold in flour, baking soda, and salt, until batter is well combined, but try not to over mix.", "Spread batter into prepared pan and bake for 20 minutes.", "While the slice is baking, heat the cream gently in a small saucepan. Turn off heat and add the chopped chocolate. Stir well with a heat-proof spatula until it all comes together. Allow to cool slightly. You can also melt the chocolate and cream together over a double boiler.", "When the slice comes out of the oven, cool for 10 minutes then pour the ganache over the top and spread evenly. Put into the fridge for another 10 minutes and then it is ready to eat."]
